16284.description: Put out by Amazon.com, it is simple book trivia game. You travel round the board, and get asked questions based on the space where you land. There are five clues per question. The first person gets 1 clue and a chance to answer. If they don't the second player gets another clue and a chance as well, going around until someone gets the correct answer. Since the reader does not participate in this process, the game is much better with more than 2 players.

16285.name: Battles of the First Empire: Marengo
16285.description: "A Battalion-Squadron level simulation of Napoleon's hard fought victory at Marengo, 1800."

16286.name: Purdueopoly
boardgamepublisher: Late for the Sky Production Company
16286.description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The Purdue University version of the classic game.

16287.name: Flotilla
16287.description:
From the Rule book:
"Flotilla is a large-scale starship combat system, designed to allow large fleets to do battle over an entire solar system. The scale is one inch per Astronomical Unit (1 AU = 93,000,000 miles = The distance from the Earth to the Sun). Each turn lasts 10 seconds, and each inch of movement is equivalent to fifty times the speed of
light."

16288.name: Battle for Paradise
16288.description:
Battle for Paradise is two games in one. The first is a strategic board game for two players. The goal is to capture and hold cities on a contested island paradise. Points are scored each turn for every city held. The winner is the first player to reach 100 points.

The second game uses the Budget Battlefield* tabletop gaming system from Microtactix Games. Battle for Paradise supplies statistics for all units in the boardgame, and stand-ups for all of the vehicles (use the stand-ups supplied with Budget Battlefield for Infantry). Why settle a battle with a die roll when you can play it out!

16289.name: Memory Spin & Match
16289.description: This memory game uses a plastic case covered with doors. A picture wheel is inserted into the case and is spun with a lever. On your turn, you open two of the doors and show the pictures revealed to all the players. If the two pictures match, you open two more doors and so on. If the pictures don't match, you close all the doors and pass the case to the next player. The first player that opens all the doors on a single turn wins.

16290.name: Twelve Teepees Memory
16290.description: In this game, players try to hide all 5 of their Indians under teepees. The Indian pawns are placed in the center of the board and surrounded by the teepees. On your turn, you look under 1, 2 or 3 teepees depending on the number you spun on a spinner. If a teepee is empty, you place one of your pawns beneath it. If a teepee is covering another player's Indian, you exchange it for one of yours and return the opponent's pawn to the middle of the board. The first player to cover all 5 of his or her Indians is the winner.

16291.description:
The gameboard represents a gully grid. A game about horse droppings and flies.

The circular game board is divided into six sectors of different color. Each sector has 15 empty fields (cobble stones). Every player selects one sector as his home turf. The aim of the game is to fill all fields of a single sector with tokens (flies) but keep your own sector clear. Players roll dice and move special tokens (horse droppings) to attract the flies into the sector of their opponents. The player whose home sector holds the fewest fly tokens at the end wins the game.

Flycatcher is a derivative of the game Circus Roncalli which was published by Schmidt in 1986.

Edition Spielbox No. 61
16291.name: Fliegenfänger

16292.name: May I? Memory Game
16292.description: In this memory game, you must ask permission from the other players to advance across the board. Each player takes 2 picture cards from the deck and places them face down on the table. The pictures on the cards (skateboard, hot dog etc.) show the spaces on the board owned by that player. On your turn, you begin advancing your pawn one space at a time along the track. You must get permission to enter a space owned by another player by saying "May I" and the name of the player that owns the space. If you do not ask permission, the owner says "Stop!", reveals the picture card and turns it face down again. You say nothing on an unowned space. You may continue moving as long as you don't make a mistake, so as more and more cards are revealed, players can travel further and further along the track during a turn. The first player to reach the finish space wins. For a more challenging game, players may draw 3, 4 or 5 cards.

16293.name: San Francisco: The Tour Game
16293.description:
Roll and land on 31 different attractions in San Francisco
using our personal Trolley Car on a main board. See all the 31 attractions and be the first to return to the airport to win. Cards help and hurt your progress as you move on the board. Score cards for each player spell out "I enjoyed everybody's favorite city" as you uncover each attraction.

16294.name: Ben-Hur Chariot Race Game
16294.description: Racing game where the players bet on which chariot will be the first to make 4 laps on the Ben-Hur-the-movie-like-race-track.

16296.name: World Cup Ski-ing '98
16296.description: A single or multi-player simulation of Downhill ski-ing. Ratings for 40 male skiers from the 97/98 season and 27 ATG male skiers are included, and there are 22 course section cards to recreate any of the 31 courses rated in the game, of which only 7 or 8 of these cards are used for any one course.

16297.name: Dinobones
16297.description:
From the box:
The bones have been uncovered. Time to build the dinosaur. Race around board collecting bones to build the dinosaur puzzle. Every time you place a bone you receive a score equal to the total number of bones played. Hang on to your bones for a higher score, but in doing so you risk losing them to another player who is hot on your heels.

1 to 4 players represented by a dinosaur pawn. There are 14 bones spaces with matching bones and scoring markers from 1 to 14.

When it is your turn you roll a die and move in the direction your pawn is facing. Depending on the space you land you can take a different action.
- Find bone can pick up a bone on the space, At the beginning of the turn, can play a bone for the next number score marker. You do not have to play a bone you have, can keep for future play.
- Bonus space – can play a bone for the next number marked and pick up a bonus marker worth 5 points.
- Lose bone – replace on map in the matching space
- Go to any bone change direction
- If you land on another players marker you may take one of his bones he has not played into the puzzle.

When all bones have been played sum all scoring and bonus markers for high score.

16298.description:
A small wargame that covers the Spanish Civil War, 1936-1939. It comes with an 8 page rulebook, map and counters. It includes 7 different scenarios to reflect different combination of foreign intervention.

Revised as

Viva España
16298.name: The Spanish Civil War

16299.description:
The box includes a 90-card deck and instructions for 3 different children games:
- Lammbada: A speed game (2-5 players, Ages 6 and up)
- Maeaehmory: A memory game (2-4 players, Ages 7 and up)
- Volle Wolle (Full Wool): (3-6 players, Ages 5 and up)
16299.name: Lamm Bada

16300.name: Hakodate 1869
16300.description: A wargame on a battle of the Japanese civil war between those factions who wanted to keep Japan closed vs. the Meiji reformers.

16301.name: Atlantis
16301.description:
A game from the Pelikan bookcase series.

The game includes two map boards (beginning and advanced) and also includes a plastic divider.

The divider is similar to those used in navigation except this one is fixed and cannot be adjusted. The player places one of the points of the divider in the start hole. The divider is then rotated until a hole matching the radius of the divider is found. There are multiple hole at this radius. One of the holes is chosen and the other point of the divider is rotated until another hole is found and chosen. This continues alternating points of the divider until the goal is reached.

An interesting solo game that seems more like a puzzle. Re-playability is somewhat limited as there are only two different boards.

The game could be extended to multiple players by keeping track of the number of times that the divider points are placed in new holes. The player with the fewest number wins.

16302.name: Battle of the Coral Sea
16302.description: Japanese wargame on the Battle of the Coral Sea. Published by Tsukuda hobbies.

16303.name: Malay Campaign
16303.description:
Japanese wargame on the Malay Campaign 1942.
Two games of "Malay Campaign"and "Capture of Singapore" are contained. Both game have different rules.

16304.name: Bingo Romano
16304.description:
A Pelikan bookcase game from their "Buchkassette" series.

This is the basic bingo game played at many locations. Includes the "Gioco Romano" variant where only motives are called not the numbers.

16305.name: Sun Tzu
16305.description: Sun Zi, Japanese multi players game of Chinese Chunjiu Zhanguo era. Published by Epoch.

16306.description:
Cubical is a fast-paced die rolling racing game with a twist.

The goal of the game is to be the first to move three dice from one side of the board to the opposite overcoming walls and obstacles along the way.

Edition Spielbox No. 62
16306.name: Cubical

16307.description:
Players roll dice and move their ships from port to port around the world, buying and selling goods specific to each port. (Ex. Players can buy beef in Buenos Aires.)

The mapboard is a map of the entire world and its oceans, with a square grid overlaying the oceans. Most major ports are depicted. Some have goods to be bought there, while others are simply destinations for goods.

Game comes with: gameboard, cargo manifests, play money,
pegs, ships, and dice.

Excellent educational game to learn geography.
16307.name: Seven Seas: The Game of Trade

boardgamehonor: 1981 Spiel des Jahres Recommended
16308.description:
A 2-player abstract strategy game where the aim is to get your 12 pieces to the opposite side. They start and must finish in 4 stacks with a 'number 3' on top, a 'number 2' in the middle and a 'number 1' on the bottom (numbers are embossed on the pieces). The numbers determine the steps each piece must move and also indicate the highest level they may climb to and move at on top of other pieces.
Also comes with 4 other variants.
Chunky wooden pieces and a gold-printed imitation-leather board add a touch of class to this Frankh/Edition Perlhuhn production.
16308.name: Ombagi

16309.name: Blank Expression
16309.description:
Ages 12 and up


of PLAYERS: 2-4 players or teams


OBJECT OF THE GAME:
Players accumulate points by filling in the missing word or words in quotes or by identifying the famous people the quotes are by or about.

EQUIPMENT:
The game includes a card holder, 64 two-sided game cards, two card screens, seven scoring pegs, and a minute timer.

TYPES of QUOTES:
There are three types of quotes in the game--
1) quotes in which one or more words have been replaced by "[BLANK]";
2) quotes about a person to be identified, which have the nouns or pronouns referring to that person underlined;
3) quotes by a person who must be identified

RULES OF PLAY:
Each game card has three categories of quotes. (EX. History, Author, Movers and Shakers) A player (or team) slides down game screen to reveal one quote in one category. All players can hear and see the quote. The current player can make a guess as to the answer, scoring points if correct, and losing points if incorrect. The player can also pass. If the player passes or is incorrect, play passes on clockwise to the next player.

OTHER NOTES:
The gamebox says that this stand-alone game is "a sequel to 'Quote, Unquote', chosen 'Best New Trivia Game' by GAMES magazine, 1994."

16310.description:
Can you see a trumpet? How about a rabbit that's pink? Now mark a path between them in this clever game of links! Take turns calling out objects and marking off the spaces. Every board has the same pictures but found in different places. You don't want to help another player win, so be careful what you name. Be the first to link two sides together and Bingo! - You've won the game!

From the publisher:

Be the first to link two sides of the same color -- and win!

There's never a dull moment with Picture Link, as every player is involved on every move.

Players take turns calling out pictures and marking them bingo-style as they try to make a path from one side of their game board to the other.

Each game board has the same pictures in different locations, so with each call you may be helping another player as well as yourself!
16310.name: Picture Link

16311.name: Dolly and Daniel Whale Game
16311.description:
Package description:
Dolly & Daniel, the two frisky little whales, usually play with the Eskimos on the icebergs of the Arctic Ocean. However, once every year, they travel to the Antarctic to visit their friends, the penguins. As they move along, they meet some friendly "spouting" whales, who help them. They also encounter some polar bears, who delay them, and 'the' angry angler who sends them back.
The girl players are "Dolly" whales and the boys are "Danny" whales.
The object of the game is to be the first whale to reach the Antarctic.

16312.name: Legion
16312.description:
Wargame Rules for Ancient Battles on the Grand Tactical Scale

Players write down their moves and then move simultaneously.

16313.description:
Louise and the Wild Goats (Luise und die wilden Ziegen) is a tactical die-rolling game.

The goal of the game is to drive your goats from the pasture into the barn making effective use of guard dog Louise. The way and number of spaces Louise moves on the board depends on the die roll. If you roll a 2, for example, Louise may jump over one or two goats Halma style. If Louise ends up on a space occupied by a goat, the goat moves one space straight on. The 12 barn spaces are worth victory points from 1 to 3. The game ends when the barn is fully filled with goats. The player with the most victory points wins the game.

Edition Spielbox No. 63
16313.name: Luise und die wilden Ziegen

16314.name: Party Scrabble
16314.description: PARTY SCRABBLE® The classic word game has a contemporary new theme with a timing feature! Score points by placing words on the playing board. But this is not ordinary Scrabble®. Play in teams with special dice. Once the timer starts, it's time to scramble! The faster you play, the more your score. Delay and your team is penalized. The team with the highest score wins! For two or more teams. Ages 10 and over.

16315.name: Star Blazers
16315.description:
Star Blazers is a very simple hex-and-counter game, based on the famous Japanese anime series Space Battleship Yamato (Uchuu Senkan Yamato). The human player/s have to make a journey from Earth to the planet Iscandar and back within a limit of 26 turns (one year simulated), to save the home planet from deadly radioactivity. The Gamilon player/s have to delay the Yamato and his escort ships, coming in their way, making their path more hazardous with the use of mines and shooting missiles.

The game movement, shooting and counter-attacks are managed by a spinner. Special damage and events are activated by the 8 cards.

Game components:
1 game board
1 plastic Yamato stand-up
5 plastic spaceships
5 round plastic parts for spaceships
1 plastic turn counter stand-up
8 special events/damages cards
30 hex counters missiles
30 hex counters mines
Stickers for the Yamato stand-up and for the turn counter
1 spinner

16316.name: Move it!
16316.description:
Move it! is a simple game simulating the transport of containers at the Europe Combined Terminals. You have to move little wooden containers from a boat to one of a maximum of six stacks (rows) and then onto a truck to be transported over land. Players can block each other by stacking containers on top of each other. Decreasing the amount of stacks in play makes the game harder.

The game was commissioned by ECT (European Container Terminal) in Rotterdam, The Netherlands, on the occasion of the completion of the Delta/Sea-Land Terminal.

16317.name: Kreuzweise
16317.description:
From a translation of the rules:

Kreuzweise was designed to play at home or when away. It is compact and the optimized material chosen for the high quality playing cards is thin, flexible and easy to clean. Where ever you play Kreuzweise, enjoy!

Basically, it's a tile-laying puzzle game where points are scored based upon the number of matching edges.

16318.name: The Antique Auction Game
16318.description:
Players take the roles of antique dealers bidding for items at auction. At the start of the game each player secretly selects eight items, represented by nicely illustrated cards, of the sixteen different antiques available (the deck includes three of each type) recording these on a score pad. Each item is likely to have a different value, representing the resale value for each player. The object therefore is to purchase as many of the selected items as possible for less than the resale price.

Players take it in turns to auction the cards. The progress of each auction is unusual in being determined by die rolls. The auctioneer rolls a die to "establish the reserve". The next player in rotation can either roll again, the value shown being added to the reserve price or drop out. This continues until only one player remains in the bidding. The cost of the item is then the sum of all the die rolls!

Items other than the eight may be purchased but at the game end they will represent a loss there is no resale value) and at any point a player may offer an item or items for sale at a price to be negotiated.
The game continues until one player has accumulated his or her
portfolio of eight items, the game ends immediately and all players calculate their profits.

The largest profit wins.

16319.name: Permission
16319.description: 'The New Property Development Board Game': in contrast to Monopoly presumably. Play comprises two stages. In stage one players travel around a a perimeter track, 'the inner ring road' on the roll of two dice, collect income on one corner and pay taxes on another. Each space represents a parking space. These give either an option to purchase either property or pick up a card and follow the instructions on it. The object is to collect a complete site made up of ten back-land plots together with a drainage easement. When a player has achieved this, movement moves to the outer (ring road?) track that is meant to represent the process of obtaining Planning Approval for the development. This is achieved by firstly collecting cards giving recommendations for approval from three separate local authority departments and then being the first to land on the town hall space: yes, on the roll of the dice and, yes, doubles mean another go!

boardgamehonor: 2009 Golden Geek Best Card Game Nominee
2009 Graf Ludo Best Family Game Graphics Winner
16320.description:
Number 5 in the Mystery Rummy series

Welcome to the 5th in a series of Mystery Rummy games, all created by Mike Fitzgerald!

Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow were notorious outlaws who robbed banks throughout the central United States between 1931 and 1935. Their exploits and charisma made them famous, and their story has been made into books and movies. Ted Hinton was the FBI agent charged with capturing them.

You are an FBI agent competing against other agents to see who can catch Bonnie and Clyde. The object of the game is to be the first to score 100 or more points.

There are two types of cards used in this game: Evidence (Location) cards and the Ted Hinton card. The game is played like the classic Rummy card game, with players playing melds and layoffs of Evidence cards to score points. The Ted Hinton card adds a strategic element to the game not found in traditional Rummy. After each hand, you total your points, and if no one has 100 or more points, you play another hand.
16320.name: Bonnie and Clyde

16321.description:
Front line by Bandai
This is a man to man level tactical combat in WW2.
Some gamers ranks this game high, especially when the details of weapon is concerned.
Another feature is there are self adhesive terrain stickers are included.
They stick to the mapboard (hard board) and are easily pealed off so they are re-usable.
This game has companion game called "Shin-ei-tai", which means "the Guards" or "SS".
16321.name: Front Line

16322.name: Strategy & Tactics
16322.description:
This is a Japanese hypothetical setting game, based on a WW2 level weapon system.
This game is intended to be an "introductory" game for newcomers.

16323.description:
This game portrays the three battles of:
El Alamein, Dunkirk and 3rd Kharkov.

Simple I-go, You-go system makes this a complete beer & pretzel package.

System and "El Alamein" designed by Yukihiro Kuroda.
"Dunkirk" designed by Masaharu Nakano.
"Kharkov" designed by Hiroyuki Okuyama.

COMPONENTS (Epoch edition)

1 rulebook
4 map board (1 for El Alamein, 1 for Dunkerque, 2 for Khar'kov)
1 counter sheets
1 counter tray
2 six side dice




COMPONENTS (Japan Wargame Classics edition)

4 rulebooks (4 pages each)
4 map sheets
1 counter sheet
1 primer guidebook (32 pages)






"Operation Compass" only included in Japan Wargame Classics edition.
16323.name: Panzer Korps

16324.name: Spots
16324.description:
Spots is a card game in which two or more players will make change from a pool of cards. Scoring is handicapped based on the difference between the total of a player's starting cards and the lowest total of the opponent's starting cards.

Players put one card from their hand into the pool, taking cards with a total value equal to or greater into their score pile. The player with the lowest score after all cards have been played wins.

Spots was designed to be a card-based version of Pennywise. It was first published in the Origins 2000 preregistration book.

16325.description:
Strike Them A Blow: 1864 North Anna River , is the fifteenth entry in the Civil War Brigade (CWB) Series from MMP. This is #15 in the series and covers the North Anna Campaign in 1864 and finally takes the system to the late Civil War period. As Robert E. Lee, can you keep the Union forces at bay, as they probe the length of the North Anna River, and the Pamunkey River? Will Cold Harbor be the pit of despair that it was in 1864? Or. as Grant, will you be able to outmaneuver Lee, and breach the outerworks of Richmond ending the war early? Only your skills will be able to dictate the course of The Civil War.
Solid game system with excellent components.

Components:

2 1/2 inch countersheets

2 34x22 map sheets.
16325.name: Strike Them a Blow

16327.description:
This is a Japanese game on "Operation Barbarossa."

This game won the 1st prize in the design competition presented by Sho-Kikaku.
16327.name: Moscow Blitzkrieg

16328.description:
Operational level wargame for carrier warfare in WW2 Pacific theater. It covers from raid on Pearl Harbor to Battle of the Eastern Solomons, also include two fictional battles.

Players will control either carrier task force of Imperial Japanese Navy or United States Navy. Players manage fleet organization, fleet movement, search for the enemy and aircraft operations. Search system use the dummy counter and the information chit.

Winner determined by victory point based on damage given to opponent ships. Also earn VP from achieve or prevent certain strategic objective.

Scenario
1. Attack on Pearl Harbor (Dec 7, 1941) Solo
2. Sinking of Prince of Wales and Repulse (Dec 10, 1941) Solo
3. Battle of the Java Sea (Feb 27, 1942) Solo
4. Carrier vs. Carrier (Fictional)
5. Battle of the Coral Sea (May 7-8, 1942)
6. Battle of Midway (Jun 4, 1942)
7.　Battle of the Eastern Solomons (Aug 24-25, 1942)
8. General Fleet vs. Pacific Fleet (Fictional)
9. Battle of the Santa Cruz Islands　(Oct 25-27, 1942) 2nd and 3rd Ed. only
10. Campaign of Solomons (1942) 2nd Ed. only
11. Indian Ocean raid (Apr 5-9, 1942) Command Magazine Japanese #15 and 3rd Ed.
12. Assault on Solomons (1942) Command Magazine Japanese #15
16328.name: Japanese Task Force

16330.description:
The Cuban Revolution depicts the critical area and time in the Guerrilla war fought between the colonial government of Fulgencio Batista and the Guerrillas led by charismatic individuals like Fidel Castro and Ernesto “Che” Guevara. Beginning in February, 1958 Castro began the first Guerrilla offensive by coming out of the Sierra Maesta Mountains and attacking the Bastiano troops in the plains. The Bastiano army counterattacked driving the Guerrillas back into the mountains beginning in June 1958. When the Bastiano army attempted to destroy the guerrillas, the Bastiano army was all but destroyed itself. With all the newly acquired weapons, the guerrillas launched a final offensive that ended in the only major battle of the war at the town of Santa Clara. The defeat of the Bastiano western forces caused the rest of the army to begin deserting. When Batista fled in January 1959, the guerrillas triumphantly declared the island was finally free. The improbable victory of the Guerrillas resulted in the only communist country in the Western Hemisphere.

The Cuban Revolution uses area movement and a simple and easy-to-learn combat system. Learning the game takes minutes and about 1-2 hours of playing time at most.
16330.name: Cuban Revolution

boardgamehonor: 2005 Charles S. Roberts Best DTP-Produced Boardgame Nominee
16331.name: Deguello at Dawn
16331.description:
In the early morning hours of March 6, 1836, after a thirteen-day siege, the besieging Mexican army surrounding San Antonio, Texas, launched a surprise attack upon the presidio of the Alamo, which was defended by U.S., Texan and Tejano volunteer militia units. The cheering Mexican soldiers, along with the accompanying bugle call of the “Deguello”, soon betrayed the surprise attack. Within an hour and a half, the entire garrison of 182 to 225 volunteers had been “put to the sword,” and General Santa Anna had won his victory at the cost of some 311 of his brave officers and soldiers. Even more, he created an American myth that began with the “Deguello at Dawn”

Dennis Bishop uses area movement, facing, ranged fire and melee combat to recreate this famous event in American History. Leaders play a big role in the game and rules for Col. James Bowie to determine if he's healthy and able to take part in the battle.

A unique twist on casualties is also used as the game has a large map (17" x 22") and uses over 400 double sided unit counters (some that are 1½" x ½") as well as about 8-10 pages of rules and various game player aids.

Deguello at Dawn was a nominee in the Charles S. Roberts awards for Best DTP-Produced Boardgame (Charles S. Roberts Awards) for 2005.

16332.description: The Battle of Tanga was the first major movement by Britain during World War 1 against the German East Africa colony. A diverse mix of colonial troops from India took part in the landings. Plagued with numerous problems, the British pressed on against the outnumbered German Schutztruppe and their Askari soldiers.
16332.name: The Battle of Tanga 1914

16333.name: Rattle Battle
16333.description: The object of the game is to catch marbles through holes in a vertical maze as the marbles fall from top to bottom.

16335.name: Space Race Card Game
16335.description:
Space Race is a simple card game designed for two players, though more can play with additional card sets (as there is no player interaction whatsoever).

The object of the game is to complete a round trip through the Solar System by drawing ten planet cards in their proper order. (The order will be unfamiliar, though, as it goes Earth -> Saturn -> Jupiter -> Mars -> Uranus -> Neptune -> Venus -> Mercury -> Earth). Each card features well executed art done in a style similar to golden age science fiction pulp magazines.

The game consists of two identical decks with cards numbered 1-10. These cards represent round trips the the Solar System, starting with "Take Off" (Card 1) and ending with "Landing On Earth" (Card 10). Players take a deck and shuffle it, then place it before them. The first player draws a card. If it is "Take Off" (Card 1), they place it in front of them and draw the next card. If the next card is a planet but not Card 2, they discard it in a discard pile next to their original pile and draw again, until they draw a card that says "Next player goes". The next player takes a turn, and draws until they get a "Next player goes" card. Chance cards such as "lost on the moon," "Sputnik," and "Danger--Comets" can affect a player's turn.

Players may draw from either pile, so there is a memory element, as you must remember which pile your next planetary target was in.

All cards must be discarded in the pile next to the pile from which they were drawn.

The goal is to collect all 10 cards, in sequence.

Rules list a variant for three or more players through using multiple copies of the game.

16336.description: The Medabots Trading Card Game, based on the children's television cartoon of the same name, allows two players to compete by placing Medabots on a Battle Sheet and fighting it out. Whenever a Medabot is destroyed, players pay a cost in Hit Points. The player who causes his opponent to lose all his HP is the winner.
16336.name: Medabots Trading Card Game

16337.description:
From the box: Join Rainbow Fish and friends in a race through the ocean. Be the first player to reach the krill feeding ground and you win!

This action-filled game, based on Marcus Pfister's book, Rainbow Fish and the Big Blue Whale, will take you on many adventures. Try to avoid the obstacles in your path, such as getting sent back by the angry blue whale's swooshing tail or getting trapped in the cave.
16337.name: Rainbow Fish and the Big Blue Whale Game

16338.description: This is a children's bingo game with a Mickey Mouse Theme. Each player receives a bingo card with a 5x5 grid of Disney characters with different colored backdrops. A spinner is used to call spaces. The outer circle of the spinner shows the various characters while the inner circle shows colors (5 per character). For example: If the spinner arrow points to the color blue and Donald Duck's face, "Blue Donald Duck" is called out. Any player with a Blue Donald picture on their card would cover it with a chip. The first player to cover 5 characters in a row with chips wins.
16338.name: Mickey Bingo

16340.name: Duel Master 4: Arena of Death
16340.description:
Similar in some regards to the Ace of Aces book series, Duel Master takes 2 players, each with their own book, into competition with one another. Play is paragraph based, with each player making their own choices about what they want their character to do.

In the Arena of Death the players take the roles of gladiators in the arena in the city Mortavalon.

16341.description: This children's card game, with a Mickey Mouse travel theme, is actually four games-in-one. In the first game, players draw an outfit card and then simultaneously grab clothing cards off the table, racing to be the first to find all four articles of their characters outfit. The second game is a simple memory game where players turn over face down clothing cards trying to (once again) complete their characters outfit. In the third game, players add an item to Mickey's suitcase and must then repeat every item (in order of the ever growing sequence) that has already been packed. The forth game is a simple rummy variant in which players try to collect all four pieces of clothing for any outfit by drawing cards from the deck or asking opponents for a specific type of card.
16341.name: Mickey Go-Along Games

16342.name: Het Grote DE Koffiespel
16342.description:
Game given by Dutch coffee company Douwe Egberts to customers which had collected a lot of coupons found on their products.

Theme of the game is coffee (really!); you are a coffee seller buying raw harvested beans and rights for different production phases (blending, roasting, packaging and distribution) to optimize the profit from selling your coffee. You can trade coffee and rights with other players.

One can also buy stock in one of the production plants (squares on the board); when you land on that square you get the rights for free, when others land on it they buy rights from you instead of the bank.

It resembles Monopoly (though it is different enough not to be called a clone) and has a similar limited-but-existing possibility for using strategy.

16343.name: The Simpsons 2 Trivia Game
16343.description:
This is basically the same as the first Simpsons Trivia Game, but with different questions. The game contains purple and green (!) cards with trivia questions as well as the same character die and poster as the first game.

This version also has different character card games: Who's Who in Springfield, Whose Wise Remark is That, and The Answer is a Question. A sheet of quotes from various characters is included for the second game.

16344.name: Surrounding Nobunaga
16344.description: A Japanese wargame on an important campaign in Nobunaga's history.

16345.name: Trafficking
16345.description:
From the new Trafficking web site:

TRAFFICKING is a role-playing board game that spoofs the cannabis trade. The game features eight dealers - Reefer T. Johnstone III, Janet Planet, Zerox Roachoid, Sonny Sgurd, Stephie "Honey Oil" Slick, Biff Spliff, D.J. Stoner and Fast Eddie Toke c pitted against a dedicated, hard-nosed Narcotics Officer, Lieutenant Dick Gumshoe. The object of the game for the dealers is to become the "Traffic King", that is to be the first dealer to sell a kilo of marijuana (36 ounces or "lids") before being BUSTED by the Narc. Should the Narc succeed in busting all the dealers before any sells a kilo, the Narc wins the game.

This classic was originally released in 1983 but is now back to get another generation of gamers high on fun!

16346.description: A race with dice. To get your die into the race roll it. Place it on the matching position. Move a die as many spaces as the die shows. If you move over another die it will change its number. First player to reach the finish line wins.
16346.name: Springprozession

16347.description: Move your pawns over clouds to win a race.
16347.name: Heiter bis Wolkig

16348.name: EastEnders
16348.description:
This game is based upon the popular BBC television soap.

From the box:
"The characters down in Albert Square have seized the imagination of the country and here's your chance to share in the ups and downs of their lives by taking on the part of one of the residents of TV's most famous square."

The goal of the game is to obtain the money to buy two rings, and then reach their character's "objective" space. Each character also has certain spaces to avoid as they move around the board. Some spaces allow the character to wager money on the dice. There are other spaces which allow all of the players to vote on how a character would respond to a dilemma given on a card.

16349.name: Call It
16349.description:
(From the game box)

The exciting game of instant decisions... Decide what your strategy will be... Make the call, throw the special dice and hope they roll your way. That's "Call It"!

Predict your dice throw and CALL IT, in this wild race game. You can Advance yourself, Setback your opponents, or do both if you CALL IT right. With the right calls, you'll be the first to reach the Finish Line. SO get ready, get set, and CALL IT!

16350.name: Measles
16350.description:
"Measles, the ultimate stacking games, combines the elements of balance, coordination and luck with strategy of attempting to outscore an opponent, or gain a scoring advantage of at least five points.

Game components include 1 base tile and 29 wooden playing tiles. Each playing tile has a pattern of red spots (measles) on its surface. Every measle is scored as one "spotpoint" following completion of a round of play.

Each of the 29 playing pieces also has 3 randomly drilled holes in it. This gives every playing tile a unique weight and balance."
...from the rules

16351.name: NBA Interactive TV Card Game
16351.description: This card game is intended to be played while watching a televised basketball contest. Each player is dealt a hand of seven cards, each with a basketball "event" such as slam dunk, blocked shot, free throw, and rebound. When a player has a card that matches the event that just occurred on the televised game, they must be the first to play it, thereby scoring the points on the card for that event (the rarer the event the more points). When a player plays all seven of their cards, he gets a seven point bonus, everyone tallies their scores and a new hand is dealt. Play continues until the end of the game and the player with the most points from completed rounds is the winner.

16352.name: The Birthday Game
boardgamepublisher: Late for the Sky Production Company
boardgameversion: Late for the Sky Production Company edition
16352.description: This is a party game for 4 or more players. The person whose birthday it is fills out a special bio questionnaire. Teams move around the board performing silly tasks and answering silly questions to advance. The first team to reach the Birthday Cake space gets a chance to answer the bio questions. The team that answers the most questions correctly wins.

16353.name: Great Day in the Park Game
16353.description: This is a Candyland type track game with a Raggedy Ann & Andy theme. The board depicts a park with a trail winding through it. On your turn, you draw a card and advance to the next space whose color matches that on the card. If you draw a picture, you move to the space on the board that has the matching picture. If you land on a puddle space, you lose a turn. The first player to reach the balloon space at the end of the track wins.

16355.name: The Difference Between Women & Men
16355.description:
Fun about stereotypes and truths.

"Why men lie and woman always buy shoes" - Who doesn't know these stereotypes? In this party game, the players note their Top-5 on a specific man-and-woman theme. This theme is either determined through a random card or made up by the players (with a picture as inspiration).
The items on Top-5's of the players are compared. Items that appear on the lists of several players are worth victory points. Therefore, while playing the game, you should try to expect what other players will put on their Top-5 list. What can women do better than men? What do men always have in the refrigerator? During scoring, fun surprises are guaranteed.

16356.name: The Yearbook Game
16356.description:
Ages 10 - 16

Manufacturer's Summary:
"The game created for girls, by girls" The questions and activities all revolve around your friends, your teachers and your classmates.

Teen and pre-teen girls love to gossip about EVERYTHING. Now, there's a game designed to encourage fast-paced, fun and non-threatening conversation that helps girls know more about themselves and each other. Your girls will love it!!

16357.name: Group Loop
16357.description:
This game was designed to be a stand-up version of "Twister";

Players have to perform various actions without falling, while intertwined in a long stretchy cord.

16358.name: Tip of the Tongue
16358.description:
From the publisher:
The Tongue-Tied game of 2-Second Trivia! Take turns answering quick-recall trivia questions and receive a point for each correct answer. The questions are not hard, but it can be a challenge to spit out the answer in the 2-Second time limit. Be the player with the most points and you win the game! The unique game case holds the cards during game play and has a built-in 2-second timer (in the shape of a tongue). Includes over 1000 trivia questions, timer, and holding case.

16359.name: Perchance
16359.description:
This Canadian offering is a hybrid of card lottery and poker, played with a large scoring board and nine differently-colored decks of cards (one for each player, plus a "dealer" deck).

The games is played in rounds, where the dealer plays a number of cards face-up, and one face-down. Players decide whether the round will be lottery-style (person with the most matches to the dealer's hand wins), or poker-style (bidding on your hand plus cards from the dealer's hand).

As an added bonus, the game promises to (and I quote from the box): "...help you and your friends lighten and brighten gloomy days, warm up cold ones and cool off hot ones."

16360.name: Road Scholar
16360.description:
A roll & move game to teach Spanish. Ages 8 and up.

From the back of the game box: Pack up your knowledge, memory, and luck and get ready to roll on a Road Scholar Spanish journey. From the START at the airport to the END at the Ancient Ruins, you'll have great fun learning an amazing amount of Spanish as you navigate the perilous twists and turns of the road.

Components: game board, English instructions, 300 word and phrase cards, Two 60-minute audio cassettes, playing pieces, colored die.

Game instructions are provided in English.

Publisher's web site: http://www.pentonoverseas.com/road-scholar.htm

16361.name: Passt Genau
16361.description:
A "look-carefully" game about abstract and spatial thinking.

The cars are parked hither and yon all across the parking lot - but illegally-parked vehicles get towed immediately! But which cards are parked incorrectly? The players need a keen eye to help out Petra the meter maid.

boardgamehonor: 2006 Golden Geek Best Kids' Board Game Nominee
2009 Boardgames Australia Awards Best Children's Game Nominee
16362.description:
In Maus nach Haus, the members of a mice family race to jump into the mouse hole before the other families can – but they're stymied in their efforts by a mouse hole that never stands still! Each round, one player spins a wooden ring, making it rotate on the table; before the ring slows and falls to the table, players simultaneously flick their mice tokens with their fingers to try to place them inside the "mouse hole" when it lands. Any mouse in the ring is removed from the game, and the first player to bring all his mice home wins.

Hula Hippos features the same game play as Maus nach Haus, but this time players have circus hippos that they're encouraging to leap through the hoop. The first player to be hippoless wins.
16362.name: Hula Hippos

16363.name: Drake
16363.description: There is a gadget that slides discs of differing size down one side, simulating a waterfall. On the discs are cubes of different colors which represent different points. If you cause these cubes to fall off during your turn, they will belong to the player before you. So this is a mix of dexterity and push your luck game.

16365.name: Mickey Mouse Club Game
16365.description: This is a "Cootie" type game in which players try to assemble one of the Mickey Mouse Club characters. On your turn you spin a spinner to see what body parts you may add. The characters MUST be assembled in an upright position, so the legs must be added first, then the body, and lastly the arms and head. The first player to complete a character wins.

boardgamehonor: 2006 Golden Geek Best Light / Party Game Nominee
16366.description:
Each player plays a character who starts the game as a teenager and then must choose the cards that will make his life take shape. He can repeat a school year and get new friends, start smoking, take part in a Bible discussion group and have his first sexual intercourse during Oktoberfest – all very realistic. Every event in the life of a character has some effect on his main characteristics - tobacco addiction, alcohol addiction, drug addiction, wealth, health, sadness, spirituality and wisdom. Excess comes at a price, though, and when a characteristic gets too high, it cancels another one – if you smoke too much, you get thin; if you get too fat, you must stop drinking; if you drink too much you lose your wisdom, and so on – once more, very realistic. During game, you can get friends, and often more, with other player’s characters. This is an important feature in the game, since what happens to you usually affects, in good or bad, your friends, and this is one of the main interaction aspects of the game.

Description from Bruno Faidutti's ideal game library.
16366.name: Funny Friends

boardgamehonor: 2005 Japan Boardgame Prize Best Childgame Nominee
16367.description: Pick A Dilly, by Hartmut Kommerell, takes place in a chicken coop. Each hen would like to be well-fed, otherwise not many eggs will be forthcoming. Only he who bluffs the best will have the most eggs at the end of the game.
16367.name: Pick A Dilly

16368.name: Wie Waldi
16368.description: In Oliver Igelhaut's Wie Waldi, the object of the game is to find blankets that match the various dachshunds. But since all of the dogs look like Waldi, it's easy to lose track of which blanket belongs to which dog. An action-packed card-laying game.

boardgamehonor: 2005 Spiel des Jahres Kinderspiel Nominee
2005 Spiel des Jahres Kinderspiel Winner
2006 Japan Boardgame Prize Best Childgame Nominee
2006 Vuoden Peli Children's Game of the Year Nominee
16369.description:
Kai Haferkamp is developing into a specialist in converting children's literature into games. After 'The Little Prince' comes this year's The Little Ghost, based on the book by Otfried Preussler. The game picks up the storyline about the players, on the stroke of midnight, spending the witching hour flitting through the dark halls of Castle Eulenstein with the little ghost. Whenever the great clock in the city hall marks the passing of another hour, a picture shows up in one of the viewing windows. Whatever is shown on the picture is what the children must now find behind the closed doors of the castle. They accomplish this with the help of a mysterious magnetic set of keys that, as if through the hand of a ghost, opens the doors of the old castle. For each correctly-opened door one receives a gleaming cannonball. How many of these balls will be required for victory is decided only by the final dexterity game in the knight's hall.

Ages 5 and up
16369.name: Das Kleine Gespenst

16370.name: Mickey Pop-Along Shape Games
16370.description: This children's pizza game, with a Mickey Mouse theme, is actually 4 games-in-one. In the first game, you pop the popper die and find the pizza that matches the shape popped. You "deliver" the pizza to the character whose hands are shown on the card. The player who delivers the last pizza wins. Game #2 is a memory game. You pop the popper and turn over a pizza card. If it matches the shape and color of the pizza you popped, you take the character card that ordered that pizza. The player with the most character cards at the end wins. Game #3 is a typical memory game where players try to get the most matching pairs. Game #4 is an advanced version of Game #1.

16371.name: James Rizzi
16371.description:
One year after releasing the highly-regarded game and art object Die HolzerSiebeN by Friedensreich Hundertwasser, Kosmos is releasing another art game, this time with James Rizzi - albeit in a much lower price category.

The game idea, invented by Reiner Knizia, is very simple but tense. The 28 large Rizzi art cards have values between 0 and 6; each of the two players receives twelve. On a player's turn, they must discard a card from their hand. To discard, a player must either create a new discard pile or place the card on an existing discard pile - but in that case, the value of the card must be exactly one higher than the card onto which it is to be placed. If there are already three discard piles on the table, then a player has no choice but to discard to one of the piles. If he can't, then he has lost the round and receives as many glass beads as cards left in his hand. The first player to get six glass beads is the loser.

James Rizzi is part of the Kosmos two-player series.

As of 2006 -- It appears that this game may never have been published.

boardgamehonor: 2005 Deutscher Lernspielpreis "3 years and up" Nominee
2005 Deutscher Lernspielpreis "3 years and up" Winner
2005 Kinderspielexperten "5-to-9-year-olds" Nominee
16372.description: Pizzas seem to be popular with Kosmos these days. In addition to the 'Pizza of Catan' (a promotional tie-in with a Geman pizza company), they are publishing a game called Pizza Flitzer (Pizza Speeders) by Gordon MacLeod. Paul and Paula are the fastest pizza deliverers around. Their good reputation is influenced by the fact that pizzas occasionally slip out of their hands. Clumsiness? Nope! Paul and Paula can simply only deliver pizzas that they are magnetically attracted to. Pizzas of the wrong pole rebuff Paul and Paula. The two of them need a little help. Someone will surely remember which pizzas the two of them should be delivering. The game includes a round wooden game board that looks like a pizza with an arrow spinner in the middle, nine magnetic pizza pieces and two magnetic figures. The two figures, Paul and Paula, have different poles (positive and negative) to ensure that they are never attracted to the same pizza. The spinner determines which figure a player, on their turn, may hold over a pizza piece. If they choose correctly, the pizza, with a click, fastens itself to the figure. The winner is the player who owns three pizza pieces first.
16372.name: Pizza-Flitzer

boardgamehonor: 2006 Golden Geek Best Kids' Board Game Nominee
2006 Japan Boardgame Prize Best Foreign Game for Beginners Nominee
2006 Kinderspielexperten "8-to-13-year-olds" Nominee
16373.description: Heinrich Glumpler is well-known for his original game ideas. With Zauberstauber (Magic Duster), he's tackled witches - but not the kind of witches that are known to most, that is, wrinkled old crones that fly about on dusty broomsticks. His new generation of witches are totally hip and savvy, and they use high-tech vacuum cleaners to take to the skies - those would be the Magic Dusters. The complicated magical duster technology makes special demands of its pilots. In the good old days, you could simply sit on your broomstick and fly off. But now, the flight pattern of the duster must first be properly programmed into the machine. No surprise then, that witches who aren't yet completely familiar with the new technology often end up on the wrong track while programming their flight routes.
16373.name: Techno Witches

16374.name: Mickey The Balancing Baker
16374.description: This game features a Mickey Mouse dressed like a baker. He stands on a wobbly base and holds an empty tray in each hand. All players take an equal number of pie pieces from the supply. On your turn, you place one of your pies on either of Mickey's trays. If you place it without having it, or any other pie already on the tray(s) fall off, your turn is over. If the pie falls, or knocks off any of the pies already on Mickey's trays, you must take the fallen pies and add them to your supply. The first player to get rid of all of his or her pies wins.

16375.name: Xabungle: Walker Gallia
16375.description:
This is a Japanese science fiction wargame set in the anime world of Xabungle.

This is a ground combat game in Zola.

16376.name: Iga versus Koga
16376.description:
This is a tactical ninja wargame based on the struggles between Iga and Koga clans in Japan.

Published by Bandai.

This game is an area type game.
However, "Storm Over Arnhem" is different systems.


Setup
Decide Ninja's ability
Ninja's ability (eight abilities) is decided(Movement,Detection,Magic ability,Combat Rating,Quickness,Physical strength,recovery power,Ninjyutu).
It gives a name at the end.

Appearance unit
Ninja and Samirai;Casket;
The ninja turns inside out at the time of initial arrangement and arranges it.
The back is disguised as the samurai.





System
Sequence of Play



1.First Player:First movement Phase
2.First Player:Combat Phase
3.First Player:Second movement Phase
4.Second Player:First movement Phase
5.Second Player:Combat Phase
6.Recovery Pahse:Both Player

Basis of movement
It is not possible to move diagonally though a length movement or a horizontal movement can be done because it is an area type movement.
The movement can be moved the below the floor level and back of the ceiling.

16377.name: East West
16377.description:
TWO CIVIL WAR BATTLES: VALVERDE & OLUSTEE

Tactical scale: 75 yards/hex, 100-125 men/unit

DTP format with unmounted color counters and color map

boardgamehonor: 2000 Charles S. Roberts Best World War II Boardgame Nominee
16378.description:
This is a Japanese tactical level game on the battles of the 1944 Western Front during World War 2.
Platoon level game of tactical battles.

Eleven scenarios from June 1944 to December 1944 from Normandy to the Bulge.

Tank types of the German, British and US armies are there.
16378.name: Panzer Grenadier

16379.name: Operation Winter Storm
16379.description:
SGB-20 Op. Winter Storm (1986) (JPY 5,800) One mapsheet, 504 counters, two identical PACs, one 24-pg rule/scenario booklet (3 scenarios), and one Historical Softbound book entitled “Photographic Series of the East Front-Operation Winter Storm” (72-pg) (JPY 1,800). The historical softbound appears to have been available separately, but I have three copies of this game and they both came with this item.

Unit scales are infantry divisions, armored brigades/regiments and Soviet Mechanized Corps. Losses are handled by steps with extra Kampfgruppen for the Germans. The map stretches from Rostov-na-Donau to Stalingrad and from Kotelnikovo to north of Millerovo. Each turn is four days and covers Nov. 19th thru Jan. 21st. Supply is tracked by point for individual armies.

16380.description: In this game, players assume the roles of Power Rangers on a 3-D gameboard. First, you must roll at least a "5" to turn into a Ranger. Then, you must defeat the Putty patrols on your path by rolling a number higher than the patrol's strength. Power Chips may be used to increase your die roll. Once all the Putties are defeated, you roll two dice to battle the Space Alien on your path. For the final battle, you roll three dice to attack King Sphinx. If all players have defeated all the Space Aliens, a Megazord is built allowing players to roll four dice in the final battle. The first player to defeat King Sphinx wins.
16380.name: Mighty Morphin Power Rangers Game

16381.name: Mighty Morphin Power Rangers Audio Game
16381.description: This is actually 2 games that use an audio cassette to direct the game play. Game #2 (Side B on the tape) is a more complex version of Game #1 (Side A on the tape). To start each player takes a board that depicts all 5 Teen Heroes. The tape will tell you when to draw cards and when to battle. The object is to cover your Heroes with their Power Ranger counterpart cards. A Rita Repulsa card may be played on an opponent to make him or her lose a turn. A Putty card is immediately discarded (thus wasting a draw). A Space Alien card may be placed on an opponents Power Ranger card forcing that player to play another Ranger card on that space. A Megazord card defeats a Space Alien and/or prevents further attacks on that space. The first player to morph all the Teen Heroes on his or her game board into the corresponding Power Rangers wins.

16382.name: Zankobst
16382.description:
From the publisher:

Four angry families quarrel in the labyrinth-like garden about the fruit. The fathers send their sons to collect the fruit while they try to steal it from the other's sons. The maze changes with every turn and if you don't pay attention, you'll get nothing home at the end.

16383.name: Bauwerk
16383.description:
From the publisher's website:

You try to build bridges on your construction-site. This results in real chaos and soon the first parts will be falling to the ground. Try to keep your eye on your strategy to get the highest score. Limited edition of 150 pieces, numbered and signed by the author.

Each player gets four little plots on the back of the game-box. Depending on the number of empty plots, a player gets material at the beginning of his turn. Now he can use this material to build connections between his plots. There are different building-styles which are more or less difficult and therefore result in more or less points. A player can also use the already built parts of the other player, which is easier and therefore results in less points. If you manage to build very complicated connections, you'll get more points. After a while, the board will be full of chaotically arranged bridges. If something falls, you'll get penalty, so be careful! Once all plots are connected, the game is over and if you didn't plan carefully you again get a penalty.
